title: 111_hr2891
content: The "Access to Frontline Health Care Act of 2009" includes a Frontline Providers Loan Repayment Program under Subpart XI of the Public Health Service Act. The "Access to Frontline Health Care Act of 2009" establishes a Frontline Providers Loan Repayment Program. Eligible individuals must serve as a health professional for at least 2 years in a frontline care scarcity area in exchange for student loan repayments. The Loan Repayment Program requires individuals to serve as a health professional for a minimum of 2 years in a frontline care scarcity area. Eligibility involves submitting an application and signing a contract with the Secretary. The Loan Repayment Program requires individuals to serve in a care scarcity area for a minimum of 2 years. To participate, individuals must submit an application and sign a contract with the Secretary for approval. The Loan Repayment Program requires individuals to serve in a care scarcity area for a minimum of 2 years upon approval of their application and contract by the Secretary. Preference is given to applicants with interdisciplinary studies background. The Secretary determines the areas for placing contract recipients. The Secretary gives preference to applicants with interdisciplinary studies background for the Loan Repayment Program. Areas for placing contract recipients are determined based on frontline care scarcity areas with demonstrated interdisciplinary health care programs or plans. The Secretary gives preference to applicants with interdisciplinary studies background for the Loan Repayment Program and determines placement areas based on demonstrated interdisciplinary health care programs or plans. Written notice is provided promptly upon approval of participation in the program. The Secretary provides written notice promptly upon approving an individual's participation in the Loan Repayment Program, which includes a contract for student loan repayment. The Secretary provides a written contract to an individual for student loan repayment in exchange for frontline care services. The individual agrees to accept student loan repayment in exchange for providing frontline care services for a minimum of 2 years at a healthcare facility in a scarcity area. The individual must serve full-time for at least 2 years at a healthcare facility in a frontline care scarcity area. Financial obligations are contingent on funds being appropriated for student loan repayment. The contract outlines damages for breach. The individual's obligation to serve at a healthcare facility in a frontline care scarcity area is dependent on funds for student loan repayment. The contract specifies damages for breach and includes statements on rights and liabilities. The contract outlines the individual's obligation to serve in a healthcare facility in a care scarcity area, dependent on funds for student loan repayment. It includes statements on rights and liabilities, as well as the amount and method of loan repayment determined by the Secretary. The Secretary determines repayment amounts for individuals in the loan repayment program, considering the need to recruit healthcare providers. Payments can be made directly to the loan provider. Breach of contract results from failure to begin service as outlined. The individual may contract with a loan provider for payment of student loan repayments. If the individual breaches the contract by not fulfilling their service obligation, the United States can recover the total amount paid under the contract plus interest. If an individual fails to fulfill their service obligation, the United States can recover the total amount paid under the contract and interest. A 'frontline care scarcity area' is defined as a designated health professional shortage area or by the State. The term 'frontline care scarcity area' is defined as an area, population group, or facility designated as a health professional shortage area or by the State due to a shortage of frontline care services in the fields of general surgery, optometry, ophthalmology, chiropractic, and physical therapy. The term 'frontline care scarcity area' is designated by the State as having a shortage of frontline care services in various healthcare fields such as general surgery, optometry, ophthalmology, chiropractic, and physical therapy. The term 'frontline care scarcity area' is designated by the State as having a shortage of healthcare services in fields such as general surgery, optometry, ophthalmology, chiropractic, physical therapy, audiology, speech language pathology, pharmacies, public health, podiatric medicine, dietetics, occupational therapy, general pediatrics, respiratory therapy, medical technology, otolaryngology, or radiologic technology. These services are provided by professionals such as general surgeons, optometrists, ophthalmologists, chiropractors, physical therapists, audiologists, speech language pathologists, pharmacists, public health professionals, podiatric physicians, registered dieticians, and occupational therapists. The term 'frontline care scarcity area' is designated by the State as having a shortage of healthcare services in various fields. These services are provided by professionals who have completed an appropriate course of study offered by an accredited institution of higher education in the United States. For the purpose of carrying out this section, there are authorized appropriations as follows: $78,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $93,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, $108,000,000 for fiscal year 2012, and $123,000,000 for fiscal year 2013. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2014 to 2016 are $138,000,000, $153,000,000, and adjusted annually based on health professions education costs. For fiscal year 2016 and onwards, the amount appropriated will be adjusted based on the average percentage increase in health professions education costs. The Secretary must start implementing the loan repayment program within 180 days of this section's enactment.
